node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text:
In America, black people are almost twice more likely to die from covid-19 as white people. Our journalists explain how the pandemic has illuminated systemic racism in America. 

Cover image credit: Getty Images

node.text:
Why are so many Americans still unvaccinated? The Economist’s data journalist Elliott Morris joins our “Checks and Balance” podcast to explain how new data modelling sheds light on vaccine hesitancy.⁠
⁠
Also on our podcast, Tamara Gilkes Borr, our US policy correspondent, reports from Arkansas where a new wave of infections is emerging. And find out how the trade-off between liberty and public health dents Americans’ life expectancies.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to “Checks and Balance” in full

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Middle East & Africa What an attack on an oil tanker says about Iran SSS MERCER STREET'.

node.text:
Last week an unmanned drone laden with explosives was flown into the MV Mercer Street, an oil tanker managed by an Israeli-owned firm, just off the coast of Oman.⁠
⁠
Two people on board, a British national and a Romanian citizen, were killed.⁠
⁠
According to America, Britain and Israel, the strike was the work of Iran. However, Iran quickly denied involvement—while ratcheting up the tension.⁠
⁠
The situation complicates efforts to revive the nuclear deal signed in 2015 by Iran and six world powers.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why America and Britain may want to limit any response to the strike.⁠
⁠
Photo Credit: AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Finance & economics Imagine the value of bitcoin fell to zero How would that look? 00 O'.

node.text:
⁠
Only a year ago there were about 6,000 currencies listed on CoinMarketCap, a website. Today there are more than 11,000.⁠
⁠
Despite bitcoin’s increasing popularity with investors, its price is far from stable. Every downwards lurch raises the question of how bad the fallout might be. We imagined what would happen if bitcoin hit zero. ⁠
⁠
Our extreme scenario suggests that leverage, “stablecoins” and sentiment are the main channels through which any crypto-downturn, big or small, will transmit more widely.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why a bitcoin crash could puncture the entire crypto economy.⁠
⁠
Illustrator: @satillustration

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Finance & economics Despite climate concerns, demand for dirty fuels is surging'.

node.text:
Despite pledges to tackle climate change, dirty fuels are surging.⁠
⁠
There has been an increase in demand for natural gas and coal as the global economy bounces back from the pandemic. ⁠
⁠
Global electricity demand is forecast to grow by nearly 5% in 2021 and by 4% in 2022. Fossil­ fuel-based power will probably make up 45% of the extra demand this year and 40% next year.⁠
⁠
The fossil-fuel surge offers a warning and politics has done little to tamp down the flames. Tap the link in our bio to read about fossil fuels' comeback.⁠
⁠
Credit: George Frey/Bloomberg

node.text:
A fourth wave of covid-19 infections is washing across America, thanks to the Delta variant.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Yet vaccinations have stalled at around 155m adults, or 60% of America's adult population. Why?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Using polling from YouGov and demographic profiles of 24,000 Americans, our data journalists have built a statistical model to estimate how likely each respondent is to say they have received, or will get, their jab.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It reveals that the single greatest predictor of whether an American has been vaccinated is whether they voted for Joe Biden or Donald Trump last November. Mr Biden's supporters are 18 percentage points likelier to get their jabs than those who voted for Mr Trump. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To learn more about which Americans are against the jab and why, tap the link in our bio

node.text:
“Skateboarding makes me feel free, like I’m flying.” Sky Brown will compete in #Tokyo2020 on Wednesday. ⁠
⁠
The 13-year-old skateboarder became the first female skater to land a frontside 540 (when you spin one-and-a-half times counter-clockwise) at the age of eight.⁠
⁠
Last year @1843mag spoke to Sky about her dream: “I just want to get out there, crush it and have fun.”⁠
⁠
As skateboarding makes its debut at the Olympic games, click the link in our bio to read how Sky does it. ⁠
⁠
Credit: © guardian/eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 4 people and outdoors.

node.text:
Singapore is less racially harmonious than its government likes to think.⁠
⁠
Several incidents have provoked a reckoning over race, until recently a taboo subject. That reckoning has penetrated even the halls of power.⁠
⁠
Singapore’s ruling party sees itself as the guardian of “racial harmony”. Yet many members of minority groups feel they are treated unfairly. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why tensions have been simmering for decades.⁠
⁠
Credit: Edgar Su/Reuters

node.text:
Facebook is on track to exceed $100bn in sales this financial year. ⁠
⁠
With 2.9bn daily global users, the platform’s main offerings—its flagship social network, photo-sharing on Instagram and messaging on WhatsApp and Messenger—are a digital magnifying glass of human nature.⁠
⁠
It also serves as a remarkable lens for advertisers to focus on the world’s consumers. Ads generate 98% of Facebook’s revenue.⁠
⁠
Mark Zuckerberg’s firm earns $8 a quarter for every one of its users, nearly twice as much as Twitter.⁠
⁠
But the success of rival platforms, such as Snapchat and TikTok, means Facebook’s share of global social-media advertising has been edging down since 2016.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read how the social network plans to deal with the competition.⁠
⁠
Credit: @brett.ryder.illustration

node.text:
What does the story of messenger RNA, or mRNA, reveal about the nature of innovation?⁠
⁠
On “Gamechangers”—a podcast series from The Economist, sponsored by Morgan Stanley—we speak to the pioneers of this technology about its unexpected path to creation, the obstacles along the way, and its vast potential for future therapies.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to “Gamechangers” in full

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 02, 2021. May be a cartoon of 2 people and text that says 'Business Will Nvidia's huge bet on artificial-intelligence chips pay off?'.

node.text:
Nvidia is a company whose market value has increased from $31bn to $486bn in five years and which has eclipsed Intel, once the world’s mightiest chipmaker.⁠
⁠
Its products are used in all data centres that make up the computing clouds operated by Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Alibaba. ⁠
⁠
Now it plans to expand further, with a $40bn acquisition of a Britain-based company called Arm, which designs zippy and energy-efficient chips for most of the world’s smartphones.⁠
⁠
But competition is fierce. It is not the only firm to have spotted an opportunity in AI, and competitors are proliferating.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read about the prospects for Nvidia, whose systems have been adopted by every big information-technology firm, as well as by countless scientific research teams in fields from drug discovery to climate modelling.⁠
⁠
Credit: @klawerzeczy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and text that says 'Middle East & Africa Letting Pegasus fly: why Israel is loth to regulate its spyware exports STOP AFTER SPYING US STOP NSO PEGASUS CRIME AGAINST HUMANITY'.

node.text:
When it was revealed that Pegasus, software created by Israel’s NSO Group, had been used to hack into the smartphones of politicians, human-rights activists and journalists, the Israeli government shrugged. ⁠
⁠
“Arms companies can’t keep track of every riﬂe and bullet they sell to legitimate customers. Why should we have higher expectations when it comes to software?” asked an Israeli defence exporter. ⁠
⁠
The Pegasus customer list correlates neatly with many of the governments courted by Israel’s former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu. Naftali Bennett, Israel’s new leader, also has close ties with the cyber-industry. ⁠
⁠
Investors in Novalpina Capital, a private-equity ﬁrm that owns NSO, are thinking of liquidating the fund. But tap the link in bio to learn why Israel’s rulers, old and new, have fewer qualms.⁠
⁠
Credit: Alamy

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 02, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'China Amid extreme weather, China avoids mention of climate change'.

node.text:
Flooding killed scores of people across Henan province in China. Some of them died in subway trains and road tunnels that remained open.⁠
⁠
Why did this happen after meteorologists issued a red-alert warning of lethal weather?⁠
⁠
Locals speak very little of the floods. When they do, they often say it was “a once-in-a-1,000-year rainstorm”. Some are fearful of speaking to foreign media about how many actually died in the floods in or around Mihe, in case they were to say something forbidden.⁠
⁠
If China’s citizens were allowed a more informed debate about why disaster struck in Mihe, some of that same energy might just help to save the world. Click the link in our bio to find out more.⁠
⁠
Illustrator: @hannabarczyk
